awd_titl_txt: New Frontiers in Synthesis of Main Group Systems with Novel Photophysical Properties
awd_abstract_narration:
The United States is in need of more economical means to manufacture highly efficient lighting and displays. Methods that can rely upon inexpensive and abundant elements and ones that minimize the formation of wasteful and toxic byproducts are especially attractive. To meet this need the Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation supports the research of Professor John D. Protasiewicz of the Case Western Reserve University into the preparation of low cost/lightweight/processable plastics and materials related to light emitting technology. Examples, include polymers, molecular electronics, light emitting diodes, photovoltaics, and flexible electronics. The students and postdocs trained and educated as part of this research program are needed as part of the country's highly skilled workforce in industry and education.  In addition to the technical broader impacts related to advanced manufaturing, Professor Protasiewicz co-organizes and runs special orientation programs directed at raising awareness of mental health issues among graduate students and faculty.
  
Main group systems with novel reactivity and bonding modes are examined to advance and create new paradigms in photophysical chemistry. Building on recently developed multiply-bonded organophosphorus chemistry dynamic carbene chemistry, electropolymerization, and fluorescence turn-on chemosensors are explored.  Isolable carbenes are examined as control elements in dynamic photochemical systems.  Luminescent and functional derivatives of 1,3-benzoxaphopsholes (BOPs) and 1,3-benzazaphopsholes (BAPs) are examined to create P,O- and P,N-chelated complexes to serve as robust functional materials for light emitting diode applications.  New routes to materials containing photoactive BOPs and BAPs are developed, as well as new types of electropolymerization reactions to produce materials with electrochromism. The Professor Protasiewicz co-organizes and runs special orientation programs directed at raising awareness of mental health issues among graduate students and faculty.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The Synthesis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation supported (CHE 1955845) the research of Professor John D. Protasiewicz of the Case Western Reserve University for fundamental research involving the synthesis and characterization of main group compounds having novel photophysical properties.  

The Broader Impacts of these studies sought to provide better understanding of how materials having elements with unusual bonding and structures can be created in order to achieve unusual and useful optical properties.  In particular, our group looked at how new compounds might impact the transformations of energy involving light in its various mechanisms, including photoluminescence, phosphorescence, and electroluminescence.  These fundamental areas are significant for the search for new low cost/lightweight/processable plastics and materials related to light emitting technologies such as molecular electronics, light emitting diodes, photovoltaics, and flexible electronics.  The students (undergrads, grad students, and high school) and postdocs trained and educated as part of this research program are valued as part of the country's highly skilled workforce in these and other STEM related areas. In addition to serving as a mentor to students and fellow faculty, Professor Protasiewicz co-organizes and runs special orientation programs directed at raising awareness of mental health issues among graduate students and faculty.  Protasiewicz has also served the greater Inorganic Chemistry community by extensive volunteer services to the ACS Division of Inorganic Chemistry.

The Intellectual Merits of this research concerns the synthesis and characterization of main group materials with novel reactivity and bonding modes are examined to advance and create new paradigms in photophysical chemistry. These novel materials possess novel properties compared to purely organic analogues, and offer opportunities to create new types of advanced functional materials including organic conjugated polymers & molecules, OLEDs, OPVs, flexible electronics, and various energy conversion technologies.  The work on this grant builds upon the PI's past successes in the development of multiply-bonded organophosphorus chemistry.  Specifically, luminescent and functional derivatives of 1,3-benzoxaphopsholes (BOPs) and 1,3-benzazaphopsholes (BAPs) were examined to create P,O- and P,N-chelated complexes to serve as robust functional materials for light emitting diode applications. New routes to materials containing photoactive BOPs and BAPs were developed.  The areas of study also included:  (i) BOPs as Unexpected and Unusual Ligands  (ii)  Computational Studies of BOPs  (iii)  Functional BOPs  (iv)  Fluorescent Benzazaphospholes (BAPs) (v) Reactions of Benzazaphospholes (BAPs) with Carbenes  (v) Dynamic Studies of Carbenes & NH Containing Fluorophores  (vi) PH/OH Cross Dehydrocoupling Reaction of ortho-Phosphinophenol.  This work has been disseminated broadly through a number of publications in prestigious journals and through various invited talks at national and international conferences.  International collaborations with scholars in the US, Germany, Spain, and Hungary have advanced and enriched our research efforts.

Last Modified: 06/03/2024
Modified by: John D Protasiewicz
